newsitem.title: USA: Hilton Hotels sees links with ITT operations.
newsitem.headline: Hilton Hotels sees links with ITT operations.

text.p: Hilton Hotels Corp said its plan for ITT Corp would likely call for combining some facilities as part of its cost-savings goal.

In a presentation to investors at a Montgomery Securities hospitality conference, Hilton Chief Financial Officer Matthew Hart said he anticipated uniting kitchen, laundry facilities and hiring centers.
"We see lots of opportunity for those kinds of things," he said.
Hilton, which last week made a $6.5 billion hostile bid for ITT, has estimated annual cost savings of $100 million from the proposed union.
ITT's board of directors is slated to consider the bid at a Tuesday meeting but is not expected to make a decision on the $55 per share cash and stock offer.
Hart declined to discuss how much Hilton would be willing to raise its offer. The company last week said it would consider a higher bid if it won access to ITT's financial data.
"We've put a strong offer on the table and we'll wait for a response," said Marc Grossman, senior vice president of corporate affairs.

He also would not comment on specific plans for ITT's $3 billion capital expansion program. In announcing its offer last week, Hilton said a substantial portion of the spending would be unneccesary if the two companies merged.

Hilton is widely expected to appeal to ITT's shareholders in the proposed transaction. ITT's stock has fallen sharply in recent months and the offer made by Hilton represents a 29 percent premium over its recent stock price.
Hart would not discuss whether Hilton has begun meeting with ITT shareholders.
Over the weekend, ITT chairman Rand Araskog rejected an offer to meet with Hilton chief executive Stephen Bollenbach.
